RACT- CAIR- BART Stakeholder Meeting January 31, 2006
RACT- CAIR- BART
Stakeholder Meeting
January 31, 2006

Massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection Bureau of Waste Prevention
Massachusetts Department of Environmental
Protection
Bureau of Waste Prevention

Purpose of Meeting
Purpose of Meeting

Over the next 1-3 years, states must revise their State Implementation Plans (SIPS) to address requirements of 3 EPA rules: • 8-hour Ozone Standard • Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR) • Regional Haze/Best Available Retrofit
Over the next 1-3 years, states must revise
their State Implementation Plans (SIPS) to
address requirements of 3 EPA rules:
• 8-hour Ozone Standard
• Clean Air Interstate Rule (CAIR)
• Regional Haze/Best Available Retrofit

Technology (BART) rules
Technology (BART) rules

Purpose of Meeting
Purpose of Meeting

• Provide background on upcoming SIP
• Provide background on upcoming SIP

requirements;
requirements;

• Provide an overview of ongoing planning to
• Provide an overview of ongoing planning to

meet these SIP requirements;
meet these SIP requirements;

• Preview potential strategies to meet 3 EPA rules that may affect MA stakeholders.
• Preview potential strategies to meet 3 EPA
rules that may affect MA stakeholders.

• Identify questions and issues.
• Identify questions and issues.

• “BART eligible” sources under the

Regional Haze program.

8-Hour Ozone – MA Status
8-Hour Ozone – MA Status

• MA is non-attainment statewide with a
• MA is non-attainment statewide with a

classification of “moderate.”
classification of “moderate.”

• MA ozone SIP revisions required:

• September 2006 – Reasonably Available

Control Technology (RACT) SIP

8-Hour Ozone – OTC Planning
8-Hour Ozone – OTC Planning

What are we doing to meet ozone SIP requirements? • MassDEP is participating in Ozone Transport Commission (OTC) regional planning process (12 states and D.C.).
What are we doing to meet ozone SIP requirements?
• MassDEP is participating in Ozone Transport
Commission (OTC) regional planning process
(12 states and D.C.).

• OTC process is looking at 2 questions: 1. What amount of additional emission
• OTC process is looking at 2 questions:
1. What amount of additional emission

reductions will be needed to bring OTC states into attainment?
reductions will be needed to bring OTC states
into attainment?

2. What regional control strategies should be adopted to achieve additional reductions?
2. What regional control strategies should be
adopted to achieve additional reductions?

• Multi-state emissions inventory and modeling

effort.
effort.

• Reviewing all sources – mobile, point and area – to see what additional reductions are feasible. Includes review of reductions from EGUs that go beyond EPA’s rule to reduce EGU emissions (CAIR). Includes review of RACT for sources of NOx and VOC emissions.

to see what additional reductions are feasible.

8-Hour Ozone - RACT
8-Hour Ozone - RACT

What is RACT (Reasonably Available Control
What is RACT (Reasonably Available Control

Technology)?
Technology)?

• Required on existing stationary emission sources
• Required on existing stationary emission sources

in non-attainment areas.
in non-attainment areas.

• Defined as the lowest emission level a facility is capable of meeting through the application of control technology, considering both technical and economic feasibility.
• Defined as the lowest emission level a facility is
capable of meeting through the application of
control technology, considering both technical and
economic feasibility.

• Section 183(c) of the CAA requires EPA to “revise
• Section 183(c) of the CAA requires EPA to “revise

and update…[RACT] as the Administrator determines necessary.”
and update…[RACT] as the Administrator
determines necessary.”

8-Hour Ozone - RACT
8-Hour Ozone - RACT

1995 NOx RACT (under 1-hour ozone standard): • RACT required for facilities major for NOx
1995 NOx RACT (under 1-hour ozone standard):
• RACT required for facilities major for NOx

emissions
emissions

MA 1995 RACT Categories: • Reciprocating Engines • Combustion Turbines • Municipal Waste Incinerators • Glass Furnaces • Boilers (>20 mmBtu/hr)
MA 1995 RACT Categories:
• Reciprocating Engines
• Combustion Turbines
• Municipal Waste Incinerators
• Glass Furnaces
• Boilers (>20 mmBtu/hr)

8-Hour Ozone - RACT
8-Hour Ozone - RACT

1995 Boiler RACT based on: • Energy input capacity • Fuel type • Combustion approach (stoker-fired, face-fired, etc…) • Heat release rate • Potential Emissions Examples: • Small boilers with nameplate capacity 20-50 mmBtu/hr
1995 Boiler RACT based on:
• Energy input capacity
• Fuel type
• Combustion approach (stoker-fired, face-fired, etc…)
• Heat release rate
• Potential Emissions
Examples:
• Small boilers with nameplate capacity 20-50 mmBtu/hr

» NOx RACT = DEP-approved annual tune-up
» NOx RACT = DEP-approved annual tune-up

• Tangential fired coal burning dry bottom boilers with
• Tangential fired coal burning dry bottom boilers with

nameplate capacity > or = 100mmBtu/hr
nameplate capacity > or = 100mmBtu/hr

» NOx RACT = 0.38 lbs NOx/mmBtu
» NOx RACT = 0.38 lbs NOx/mmBtu

8-Hour Ozone - RACT
8-Hour Ozone - RACT

Now looking at RACT again - two purposes: • States must review RACT controls to meet EPA’s 8-hour ozone RACT SIP requirement.
Now looking at RACT again - two purposes:
• States must review RACT controls to meet
EPA’s 8-hour ozone RACT SIP requirement.

• OTC is reviewing RACT categories to
• OTC is reviewing RACT categories to

assess potential for tighter RACT controls within OTC as regional attainment measure.
assess potential for tighter RACT controls
within OTC as regional attainment measure.

8-Hour Ozone – RACT
8-Hour Ozone – RACT

State RACT SIP Requirement: • MA and other states that adopted RACT under 1- hour ozone standard may not need to adopt new controls.
State RACT SIP Requirement:
• MA and other states that adopted RACT under 1-
hour ozone standard may not need to adopt new
controls.

• But - must review whether what was considered RACT when previously adopted is still RACT – are there new technologies, less costly controls, other factors?
• But - must review whether what was considered
RACT when previously adopted is still RACT –
are there new technologies, less costly controls,
other factors?

• May decide to adopt new state RACT limits or that nothing more is needed to satisfy RACT. • Submit our determination to EPA as a RACT SIP.
• May decide to adopt new state RACT limits or
that nothing more is needed to satisfy RACT.
• Submit our determination to EPA as a RACT SIP.

OTC Review of RACT in OTC Region:
• reviewing multiple RACT categories as possible

candidates for tighter NOx and VOC limits
candidates for tighter NOx and VOC limits

types.

8-Hour Ozone – Timeline
8-Hour Ozone – Timeline

• Late Feb. 2006 - OTC Commissioners initial
• Late Feb. 2006 - OTC Commissioners initial

recommendations for regional control strategies, including RACT.
recommendations for regional control strategies,
including RACT.

• June 2006 – OTC Commissioners final
• June 2006 – OTC Commissioners final

recommendations for regional control strategies. May include ICI RACT measures – or not. • Jan. – July 2006 - MA review of state RACT
recommendations for regional control strategies.
May include ICI RACT measures – or not.
• Jan. – July 2006 - MA review of state RACT

controls adopted under 1-hour ozone standard.
controls adopted under 1-hour ozone standard.

• September 2006 - RACT SIP due.
• September 2006 - RACT SIP due.

8-hour Ozone – Next Steps
8-hour Ozone – Next Steps

• After OTC Commissioners make initial
• After OTC Commissioners make initial

recommendations for RACT measures (Feb.), MassDEP will follow-up with ICI boiler facilities (and other source categories) to discuss OTC recommendations.
recommendations for RACT measures (Feb.),
MassDEP will follow-up with ICI boiler facilities
(and other source categories) to discuss OTC
recommendations.

• MassDEP may propose regulations taking into
• MassDEP may propose regulations taking into

account OTC recommendations and our in-state assessment of current MA RACT requirements.
account OTC recommendations and our in-state
assessment of current MA RACT requirements.

CAIR – Background
CAIR – Background

• EPA determined the amount of emission
• EPA determined the amount of emission

reductions that each contributing state must achieve.
reductions that each contributing state must
achieve.

• Based on the level of reductions that can be
• Based on the level of reductions that can be

achieved with “highly cost-effective” controls on EGUs.
achieved with “highly cost-effective”
controls on EGUs.

• But does not require that states achieve the
• But does not require that states achieve the

reductions from EGUs.
reductions from EGUs.

• MA found to contribute only to ozone non-

methodology to set caps: 1999-2002 heat input multiplied by fuel-adjustment factors of: 1.0 for coal, 0.6 for oil and 0.4 for gas.

multiplied by fuel-adjustment factors of: 1.0 for

CAIR – Sources
CAIR – Sources

CAIR Sources: • EGU = fossil-fuel fired boiler or turbine serving a generator > 25 MW nameplate capacity producing electricity for sale. • Municipal waste combustors included but
CAIR Sources:
• EGU = fossil-fuel fired boiler or turbine
serving a generator > 25 MW nameplate
capacity producing electricity for sale.
• Municipal waste combustors included but

EPA is proposing to exempt them.
EPA is proposing to exempt them.

• Cogeneration units, as defined, are exempt.
• Cogeneration units, as defined, are exempt.

CAIR – SIP Requirements
CAIR – SIP Requirements

Other units affected: • NOx Budget (SIP Call) Program Sources –
Other units affected:
• NOx Budget (SIP Call) Program Sources –

– EPA’s CAIR trading program will replace the
– EPA’s CAIR trading program will replace the

NOx Budget Program (310 CMR 7.28)
NOx Budget Program (310 CMR 7.28)

– State option whether to include all NOx Budget
– State option whether to include all NOx Budget

Program participants in CAIR program
Program participants in CAIR program

• Potential opt-in for sources that do not meet EGU definition if: vent through a stack and meet Part 75 monitoring and recordkeeping requirements.
• Potential opt-in for sources that do not meet EGU
definition if: vent through a stack and meet Part
75 monitoring and recordkeeping requirements.

CAIR – SIP Requirements
CAIR – SIP Requirements

• State must submit a SIP showing how it will
• State must submit a SIP showing how it will

achieve CAIR-required reductions.
achieve CAIR-required reductions.

• States can achieve the reductions however they choose – control EGUs or control other sources. • If state controls only EGUs, it must adopt the state
• States can achieve the reductions however they
choose – control EGUs or control other sources.
• If state controls only EGUs, it must adopt the state

cap/budget set in CAIR.
cap/budget set in CAIR.

• If a state chooses to achieve reductions from other than EGUs, CAIR says how to set state CAIR budget.
• If a state chooses to achieve reductions from other
than EGUs, CAIR says how to set state CAIR
budget.

CAIR – SIP Requirements
CAIR – SIP Requirements

• EPA has provided a model cap and trade rule for
• EPA has provided a model cap and trade rule for

states to adopt to achieve EGU emissions • If a state wants its EGUs to participate in the
states to adopt to achieve EGU emissions
• If a state wants its EGUs to participate in the

CAIR cap and trade program, it must adopt EPA’s model rule in its CAIR SIP.
CAIR cap and trade program, it must adopt EPA’s
model rule in its CAIR SIP.

• Model rule sets out most program parameters: accounts, permits, monitoring, reporting, etc.
• Model rule sets out most program parameters:
accounts, permits, monitoring, reporting, etc.

CAIR – SIP Requirements
CAIR – SIP Requirements

States have flexibility to revise EPA’s model rule for
States have flexibility to revise EPA’s model rule for

certain program elements:
certain program elements:

• Whether to include NOx SIP Call sources that do
• Whether to include NOx SIP Call sources that do

not meet CAIR EGU definition in the CAIR ozone season NOx program.
not meet CAIR EGU definition in the CAIR ozone

• Whether to allow sources that do not meet CAIR
EGU definition to opt-in to the CAIR trading
program.

• Allocation method for state allowances (input vs.
• Allocation method for state allowances (input vs.

output, set-asides for renewables, etc.)
output, set-asides for renewables, etc.)

CAIR – SIP Timing
CAIR – SIP Timing

• Final CAIR rule (3/05) requires state CAIR SIPS
• Final CAIR rule (3/05) requires state CAIR SIPS

be filed by September 2006
be filed by September 2006

• However, in April 2005 EPA proposed a Federal Implementation Plan (FIP) incorporating CAIR provisions.
• However, in April 2005 EPA proposed a Federal
Implementation Plan (FIP) incorporating CAIR
provisions.

• Legal rationale for FIP: states failed to submit SIPs to address interstate transport following adoption of PM2.5 standard in 1997.
• Legal rationale for FIP: states failed to submit
SIPs to address interstate transport following
adoption of PM2.5 standard in 1997.

CAIR – SIP Timing
CAIR – SIP Timing

• March 2006 – EPA will promulgate final FIP rule. • FIP will impose federal CAIR program in states until EPA has approved a state’s CAIR SIP.
• March 2006 – EPA will promulgate final FIP rule.
• FIP will impose federal CAIR program in states
until EPA has approved a state’s CAIR SIP.

• FIP will set state CAIR caps/budgets for 2009 and
• FIP will set state CAIR caps/budgets for 2009 and

subsequent allocation years.
subsequent allocation years.

• But EPA will not record 2009 allowances to
• But EPA will not record 2009 allowances to

facility accounts until December 2007 – giving states time to get their SIPs approved before then, including state preferences for allocations.
facility accounts until December 2007 – giving
states time to get their SIPs approved before then,
including state preferences for allocations.

CAIR – SIP Options
CAIR – SIP Options

With FIP, states now have SIP options: • Full CAIR SIP – per CAIR Final Rule.
With FIP, states now have SIP options:
• Full CAIR SIP – per CAIR Final Rule.

State adopts state rule establishing CAIR trading program that includes all provisions in EPA’s model rule (but may include state preferences for allocation.)
State adopts state rule establishing CAIR trading program
that includes all provisions in EPA’s model rule (but may
include state preferences for allocation.)

• Abbreviated CAIR SIP – per proposed CAIR FIP
• Abbreviated CAIR SIP – per proposed CAIR FIP

and final FIP to be issued 3/06. EPA model rule goes into effect covering all provisions for state cap and trade program. By 3/07 state may submit CAIR SIP with state rule covering only state allocation preferences.
and final FIP to be issued 3/06.
EPA model rule goes into effect covering all provisions for
state cap and trade program. By 3/07 state may submit
CAIR SIP with state rule covering only state allocation
preferences.

CAIR – SIP Options

MA anticipated CAIR SIP approach: • Not planning to file full CAIR SIP by 9/06. • Will do a rulemaking to adopt CAIR Ozone
MA anticipated CAIR SIP approach:
• Not planning to file full CAIR SIP by 9/06.
• Will do a rulemaking to adopt CAIR Ozone

Season NOx trading program.
Season NOx trading program.

• Will file abbreviated CAIR SIP by March 2007
• Expect to propose a state-defined output-based

NOx allowance allocation methodology with set- asides (as in 310 CMR 7.28).
NOx allowance allocation methodology with set-
asides (as in 310 CMR 7.28).

• Will sunset MA NOx Budget Program - 310 CMR
• Will sunset MA NOx Budget Program - 310 CMR
